Generic sort
change
Change places of two elements by tapping their cells.
Please wait...
Getting data...
Start the algorithm by comparing the first two elements. If the left one is larger then the right one, exchange them and continue with comparisons of elements rightwards.
Exchange the neighbouring elements if the left one is larger then the right one.
Start pass #%d from the left. %s
The last successful exchange was between elements at spots %d and %d. Continue comparisons rightwards.
When using Bubble sort, one can only exchange neighbouring elements. %s
Start the algorithm by placing the element in the second spot into the temporary variable in the bottom right
Start pass #%d, starting with the element at spot %d. Use the temporary variable to store that element.
Finish pass #%d by using the temporary variable
Move elements to the right (starting with the element at spot %d), moving towards the beginning of the array until you find the appropriate spot for the element stored in the temporary variable.
Continue sorting by moving the element at spot %d rightwards.
Elements are moved by copying the left element into its neighbour to the right if the left element is larger then the element stored in the temporary variable.
When copying elements in the array be mindful of the order in which you do so. First select the element to be copied and then select the destination spot.
Incorrect step. The next step of the algorithm should be to copy the element stored in the temporary variable into spot %d.
Incorrect step. The next step of the algorithm should be to copy the element at spot %d into the temporary variable.
Incorrect step. The next step of the algorithm should be to copy the element at spot %d into spot %d.
Start sorting by calculating the median of the elements at spots 1, 4 and 8 by comparing them and exchanging them if necessary. If no exchanges are necessary, hide the pivot in next-to-last spot.
Calculate the median of the elements at spot %d, the (left) middle spot and spot %d by comparing them and exchanging them if necessary.
Hide the pivot in the next-to-last spot.

Find an element equal to or larger than the pivot in the elements to the right of the element at spot %d. Find an element smaller than or equal to the pivot in the elements preceeding the element at spot %d. Exchange them or return the pivot to its spot.
Return the pivot to its spot. (Spot %d)
Sort the subarray between spots %d and %d using the Insertion Sort algorithm.
%s (the first and middle element)
%s (the first and last element)
%s (the middle and last element)
%s (exchange it with the element at spot %d)
Continue. %s
Start sorting by exchanging the first element with the smallest element.
Exchange the smallest element of the array to the right of the element at spot %d with the element at spot %d.
The array is now sorted up until the element at spot %d. Continue sorting by exchanging the smallest element to the right of the element at spot %d with the element at spot %d.
Start sorting with the step hk = %d. First copy the element at spot %d into the temporary variable.
Continue sorting with the step hk = %d. First copy the element at spot %d into the temporary variable.
Compare elements at spots %d and %d. If necessary, exchange the element at spot %d with the element at spot %d.
Return the element stored in the temporary variable to the appropriate spot.
Sort using an Insertion sort pass. (hk = 1)
When copying elements in the array be mindful of the order in which you do so. First select the element to be copied and then select the destination spot.
